body.text: Iets and niets are used exactly like 'something' and 'nothing' in English. The only difference is that the Dutch do not make a distinction between 'something' and 'anything'.
Iets and niets are singular pronouns.
If we combine iets or niets with a preposition (met iets, voor niets), we can use a pronominal adverb (see further below).

table: I would like to say something.
We have not done anything yet.

body.text: Sometimes, we change the pronoun into an adverb when it is preceded by a preposition. For example, instead of voor iets ('for something'), we can say ergens voor ('somewhere for').

We do not have to do this. We are perfectly allowed to write a preposition before iets or niets. However, if we want, we can use the pronominal adverbs ergens (somewhere) instead of iets (something) and nergens (nowhere) instead of niets. If we do this, the following happens:
Note that (n)ergens is not attached to the preposition.

table: Dat deed me aan iets denken.
Dat deed me ergens aan denken.

She was not afraid of anything.
[She was afraid of nothing]

body.text: If iets or niets precedes an adjective, we add -s to the end of the adjective.

table: Er is niets interessants op tv.
There is nothing interesting on TV.
Can you think of anything better?
Er was iets vreemds aan hem.
There was something strange about him.
